results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group trip by tourist bus, four wheel drive vehicles and truck around the ‘Gulf Country’. The Gulf Country is the region of woodland and savanna grassland surrounding the Gulf of Carpentaria in north western Queensland and parts of the Northern Territory, Australia.

We see many dirt roads and sandy tracks so that we see both a tourist bus and four wheel drive vehicles being dug out of the sand. As always, Wallace includes close-ups of any flora and fauna that catch
his eye along the way.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Gulf Country’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:01:15:00 sign for ‘Four Wheel Drive’.
00:01:21:00 a large lorry style truck travelling ahead on dirt road.
00:01:31:00 digging a vehicle out of sand on a track.
00:02:30:00 tourist bus being hauled from the sandy track by a truck.
00:03:42:00 particularly colourful bird in a tree.
00:03:57:00 people in a small boat catching fish.
00:04:55:00 a row of tents for camping lined up along a riverbank.
00:07:45:00 close up of a blackened ‘billy can’ set over a fire and then a wider shot of a group of picnic-goers.
00:08:09:00 a woman in an example of a 1970s style ‘halter-neck’ top.
00:08:32:00 animal footprints in the dust followed by a large snake making progress through the grass
00:09:14:00 large truck and bus with baggage loaded on roof travel down a dusty road
00:09:57:00 cattle in stockyards
00:10:27:00 wetlands and wildflowers
00:11:45:00 swimming in a river
00:11:53:00 a close-up of a spider in the middle of a large web wit the blue of the river in the background
00:12:53:00 title card ‘The End’

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
The Wallace Clarke Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on 8mm film. Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movie Collection]
results.material_description: 13 x 200ft spools of 8mm home movie footage, plus 1 x DVD transfer of an additional spool (14 separate films in total).
results.brief_description:
The William Darbyshire Home Movie Collection is a collection of home movies originally made on Standard 8mm film, featuring travels in the 1960s.

William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sights of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group walking trip by members of the ‘Walkabouters’ club to the Grampians (Gariwerd) in Victoria. It features the making of a ‘pit oven’ style barbeque and showcases the walking to be had by visitors through the many ravines and paths but also the grandeur of the sweeping views from what can seem like perilous pinnacles and lookouts.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Dreaming Place’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 views of the Grampians range off in the distance
00:00:56:00 driving through a small township
00:02:51:00 creating a ‘pit oven’ by setting a fire in a deep hole in the ground
00:02:59:00 stones are thrown into the flames and then covered with pieces of terracotta tiles on which meat in aluminium foil is placed for cooking
00:03:38:00 the pit is covered with a piece of metal, hessian bags, stones and dirt
00:04:15:00 a woman climber is helped to the top of some rocks
00:06:10:00 cars driving along a dirt road in the bush
00:06:44:00 an example of the the beautiful rock of the Grampians
00:07:07:00 sign for ‘Forest Commision of Victoria’ ‘Camp of the Emu’s Foot’
00:07:15:00 Indigenous art on rock walls
00:09:48:00 a still river which runs under a wooden walk bridge among tall reeds
00:10:19:00 a fenced off shallow cavern possibly with Indigenous drawings on the rock
00:10:35:00 views of Indigenous drawings up close
00:11:07:00 driving through the bush
00:11:54:00 grey patchy granite rock of the Grampians
00:12:29:00 a lone walker stands on top of a high peak
00:15:25:00 walking through the bush
00:17:00:00 groups of kangaroos and emus
00:18:23:00 climbing a steep ravine
00:20:19:00 sitting on a precipice overlooking the dramatic scenery below
00:20:43:00 a large body of water, possibly Lake Fyans in the Grampians
00:23:22:00 walking along narrow pathways through the bush
00:24:14:00 sign ‘Grand Canyon’
00:25:43:00 sign ‘Echo Cave’ which appears to be painted on the rock itself
00:26:13:00 another sign ‘Pinnacle Street’ painted on a path rock
00:26:24:00 a rock worn away into the shape of a mushroom
00:26:49:00 sign ‘Silent Street’
00:28:12:00 walkers at a pinnacle lookout showing the fencing used for safety in the Grampians

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures the scenery around the You Yangs and other nature spots in Victoria. Wallace includes lots of close-ups of wildflowers along the way as well as old farm machinery, some lovely old buildings, monuments, rocky outcrops, scrub, trees and sky.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:02:35:00 walkers in the scrub
00:03:22:00 a koala peers at the camera
00:03:36:00 remains of a wooden sluice in a creek that may have been an old gold mining site
00:03:50:00 hearing instructions or a talk at a campsite with a fire
00:04:45:00 setting off on a walk through farm lands and gates
00:05:05:00 sheep run across a paddock and a swirling, foaming river spilling across rocks with spectacular waterfalls
00:06:52:00 collecting driftwood by the dramatic river
00:07:18:00 scenes showing the treacherous route for walking the banks of the swollen, fast flowing river
00:09:54:00 jumping from rock to rock over a creek
00:10:18:00 using logs to cross a creek
00:10:27:00 hikers walk up a long grassy hill with some sheep running by, toward a gravel quarry or storage area
00:11:03:00 looking for rock specimens or stones in the gravel
00:11:13:00 some hikers stop for a chat before scrambling over a rocky part of the hills
00:12:15:00 flowers, mushrooms and toadstools
00:13:08:00 a long lizard close-up followed by a centipede
00:14:40:00 a trickling creek before scenes of rushing waters in a small creek
00:15:50:00 country roads
00:16:29:00 filming a photographer taking pictures of wildflowers followed by close-ups of flowers
00:18:16:00 several wild orchids
00:19:15:00 a campfire at night
00:19:44:00 stone monument with a plaque that reads ‘Erected 1951. In memory of the pioneers of Steiglitz and the discovery of gold 1851 - 1853’
00:19:50:00 the the lovely brick Steiglitz Court House among gumtrees, a plain but lovely old house across the road and a farm cottage next to an old chimney that could be all that remains of an earlier house
00:20:33:00 a flock of ducks or geese
00:20:45:00 an old brick fireplace surrounded by the trees and bushes that have overtaken it, followed by several ageing weatherboard buildings
00:21:23:00 sign ‘Walking track to Flinders Peak’ (in the You Yangs, Victoria) followed by views from a higher vantage point in the You Yangs
00:22:19:00 views of jutting rocks and outcrops and some of the farmland beyond the You Yangs
00:23:48:00 plaque for ‘Matthew Flinders RN who stood on this rock to survey the bay’

description_for_label:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures the scenery around the You Yangs and other nature spots in Victoria. Wallace includes lots of close-ups of wildflowers along the way as well as old farm machinery, some lovely old buildings, monuments, rocky outcrops, scrub, trees and sky.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 22]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, Wallace films the city of Shanghai in China, and its people. Crowded streets, heavy traffic (with many bicycles), houses, shops and other buildings, gardens, the city’s canals and port are features. There are scenes of people at work, and children in organised cultural activities, and a sequence of high-vantage-point views of the city dissolve into one another. The Jade Buddha Temple with its many statues is also featured.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Wallace Clarke titles ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Shanghai’, ‘Filmed by W.H.C’
00:01:26:99 carpet weaving
00:02:34:00 jade ‘Buddha Temple’ and its Buddha statues
00:04:57:00 various views of the city from high vantage points, in a sequence of dissolves.
00:05:56:00 young children at school or kindergarten
00:11:50:00 port and ships
00:13:41:00 shadow puppet play
00:14:04:00 young children in various music, calligraphy, arts and electronics activities in a sequence of dissolves. Some children wear the red scarf of the ‘Young Pioneers of China’ youth organisation.
00:15:45:00 title ‘The End’

results.title: 1945-1989: the Cold War (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Sidney Platt and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Within two years of the end of World War II, the alliance between the United States and the Soviet Union was shattered and for the next 40 years global affairs were dominated by the battle for ideological and material supremacy between the two superpowers: a battle fought through espionage and propaganda. The Cold War resulted in the nuclear arms race and in the “space race”, as well as entrenching either Soviet or US domination throughout the developing world. The video explores the Cold War from the beginning of President Truman’s policy of “containment” in Greece; to the formation of NATO and the Warsaw Pact; through the Korean, Vietnam and Afghanistan wars; through the Cuban Missile Crisis; the revolts against Soviet domination in Hungary and Czechoslovakia; to the destruction of the Berlin Wall which symbolised the end of the Cold War and totalitarian Communism.

The video explores the Cold War from the beginning of President Truman’s policy of “containment” in Greece; to the formation of NATO and the Warsaw Pact; through the Korean, Vietnam and Afghanistan wars; through the Cuban Missile Crisis; the revolts against Soviet domination in Hungary and Czechoslovakia; to the destruction of the Berlin Wall which symbolised the end of the Cold War and totalitarian Communism.

results.title: 1945-1989: the Cold War
results.creator_credit: Sidney Platt and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: Within two years of the end of World War two, the alliance between the United States and the Soviet Union was shattered and for the next 40 years global affairs were dominated by the battle for ideological and material supremacy between the two superpowers: a battle fought through espionage and propaganda. The Cold War resulted in the nuclear arms race, “the space race”, as well as entrenching either Soviet or US domination throughout the developing world. The video explores the Cold War from the beginning of President Truman’s policy of “containment” in Greece; to the formation of NATO and the Warsaw Pact; through the Korean, Vietnam and Afghanistan wars; the revolts against Soviet domination in Hungary and Czechoslovakia; the Cuban Missile Crisis; to the destruction of the Berlin Wall in 1989 which symbolised the end of the Cold war and totalitarian communism.

results.title: 1929-1941: The Great Depression
results.creator_credit: Sidney Platt and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: The video offers a history of the Great Depression in the United States. The economic boom of the early 1920’s, built on speculation and deferred borrowings, ended with the stock market crash of 1929. One quarter of American working people became unemployed in a time where government health care and unemployment assistance was non-existent. The video examines the causes of the global depression; the rise of militancy in the U.S. labour movement; the depression on the land; and looks at President Roosevelt’s New Deal and some of the programs his administration initiated to assist the poor. The final end to the depression only came with the rise of Nazism in Europe and the increase in global production geared towards the war effort.

results.title: 1917: Revolution in Russia
results.creator_credit: Sidney Platt and National Geographic Society
results.brief_description: A detailed analysis of the Bolshevik revolution that transformed Russian society and which led to the creation of the Soviet Union. The video explores the reasons for the Bolshevik success including their brilliant intellectual base. The widespread opposition to the autocratic rule of the Tsars, and the famine and destruction resulting from Russia’s participation in the imperial First World War, also led to wide support for the Bolsheviks amongst the Russian population. The video also examines the pivotal role of Lenin as both theoretician and leader of the Revolution. Includes the use of archival footage of the period.
